title: Unlocking AI Success: From Strategy to Scalable Results | Juan Alfageme

rawLines.text: Welcome to Just Curious. Today I'm
joined by Juan Alphag, an AI strategist
at Deote who's helping enterprises
bridge the gap between AI hype and
execution. With a background in
industrial engineering and experience in
data pipelines, AI strategy, and
enterprise consulting, Juan blends
technical expertise with business
acumen. He's developed and deployed AI
strategies for major banks, energy
companies, and global enterprises.
Today, we'll talk about what it takes to
build a strategic AI roadmap, how to
identify high impact use cases, and why
successful AI adoption is as much about
change management as it is about the
technology. Juan, welcome to Just
Curious. Thank you for inviting me to
this interview. Yeah, of course. Can you
tell us a little bit more about your
focus on AI within Deote? Yeah, in Deoid
as an AI strategy consultant, we focus
on bridging the gap between technology
and impact. So we try to focus on how a
strategy will help maximize AI impact
return and the Roy in such a big
ecosystem as as AI is right now. What's
the first thing you do when a company
asks where should we start with AI?
Okay, so firstly we got to see where our
client is at. Sometimes our client wants
to start building genai use cases but
they still don't have even a data
governance team that can help them
extract, analyze and maximize their
data. So it's the main part and the
first part to see their AI maturity. We
usually do a AI maturity assessment to
be able to identify where we at and the
gap we need to bridge. What does that
assessment look like? What inputs do you
take into account when you're helping
someone understand if they're ready or
not? Okay, we usually take the data
part, see how our client is connecting
their their data, how are they
extracting it, where are they loading
it, and how are they using it. And
secondly, we take a look at their
technology stack. See their technology
maturity. See if they have the
technology stack to be able to implement
big Gen AI use cases or they still have
like a big gap and we need to work on
this technology architecture before
moving on. and also in the management
change to see how the their employees
are within AI, how much do they know
about AI and what kind of workshops or
or how can we try to make this change
management plan for them to maximize the
the use cases we will implement in the
future. When it comes to data, for
someone who's listening to this and
wondering whether their data is ready
for an AI strategy, what are the
considerations that come into play when
evaluating whether data is clean and
organized and ready to be ingested by a
potential solution? Mainly right now the
main pipeline it's called
ELT. It can also be ETL. It stands for
extract, load and transform. Okay. So,
you got to be able to extract the data
from whatever your activity is. If
you're a bank, you need to be able to
extract all the payments your clients
make each day. And after extracting all
the data in real time, you got to be
able to load it into your databases to
be able to have it correctly structure
over there. And then you need to or it's
easier if you are able to transform the
data that it's already loaded in your
database. So it's easier for AI to work
on that. We've just seen the MCP
protocol that open AAI just adopt from
cloud and that's a big example on how
data and structuring data will
accelerate AI adoption and what and how
AI will maximize it impact through data.
How much does that change how much work
needs to be done with regards to
structuring your data? Exactly. Well,
the MCP protocol, for example, it's a
really good example because it shows you
how just by having a a type of
guidelines on how to extract or use an a
specific type of data will help the
whole enterprise to know okay this our
data for our client part it's built this
way. It's a it's a structure in a
protocol way following these guidelines.
So every time we deploy a use case and
we need to call external data for what
could be on
ra similar where you need external
context for for an answer you know how
to call how to communicate with this
database and it's much easier because
you don't need to do um a a specific use
case communication with our databases
for each different use case. Many uh
many leaders believe AI can solve
everything, but it's rarely true. How do
you help companies separate real
opportunities from pipe dreams? Yeah,
that's mainly one of our biggest
challenge right now cuz uh a lot of
people don't know what really what AI is
or what Gen AI is cuz you start seeing
in social media and you think Gen AI can
do everything, but it's really hard to
know exactly what they can do. That's
what our expertise brings on. We usually
for identifying use cases, we can
usually do workshops with the employees
to see what their other their needs are
in their specific in their specific job.
And then with our expertise, we'll try
to convert from their necessities to an
AI use case impact. So we are the ones
that by our expertise are separating
these alunizations and these desires AI
with real use cases. Yeah. You've talked
about a prioritization matrix. Can you
walk us through that process and what
goes into evaluating value and
feasibility? Exactly. That will be the
second step of identifying use cases
which is one of the main parts of our
strategic offering. So after these
workshops I've mentioned we have a
usually a long long list of use cases
and we need to see what the real impact
is of each use case. So what we usually
do is we try to build parame
parameterization matrix which has as you
said two axis it has impact in in and
value in the business and physibility.
So for impact in the business, we
usually take a look at what's the
initial investment that needs to be made
to deploy this use case. What's the cost

What's the efficiency that this use case
will bring? And how will this
um how will this make an impact on the
on the OPEX in in our business? And then

we'll take a look at non-tangible

better look as a company cuz you're more

that impact? And this matrix has weights
which are parametricized with our
client. So if our client's strategic
plan is focusing in reducing cost or
being more echofriendly, we will have
these criterias have a bigger weight on
our matrix so that our usea our
prioritized use cases are the ones that
will feed with their strategic plans. So
same thing goes with visibility. We take
a look at the data needed for the use
case and the gap we need to close
between what what the company has with

of data for this use case their
technology stack the implementation
cost. So we take a look at how much it's
it's going to cost in effort and

cleanText:
Welcome to Just Curious.
Today I'm joined by Juan Alfageme, an AI strategist at Deote who's helping enterprises bridge the gap between AI hype and execution.
With a background in industrial engineering and experience in data pipelines, AI strategy, and enterprise consulting, Juan blends technical expertise with business acumen.
He's developed and deployed AI strategies for major banks, energy companies, and global enterprises.
Today, we'll talk about what it takes to build a strategic AI roadmap, how to identify high impact use cases, and why successful AI adoption is as much about change management as it is about the technology.
Juan, welcome to Just Curious.
Thank you for inviting me to this interview.
Yeah, of course.
Can you tell us a little bit more about your focus on AI within Deote?
Yeah, in Deoid as an AI strategy consultant, we focus on bridging the gap between technology and impact.
So we try to focus on how a strategy will help maximize AI impact return and the ROI in such a big ecosystem as AI is right now.
What's the first thing you do when a company asks where should we start with AI?
Okay, so firstly we got to see where our client is at.
Sometimes our client wants to start building genai use cases but they still don't have even a data governance team that can help them extract, analyze and maximize their data.
So it's the main part and the first part to see their AI maturity.
We usually do a AI maturity assessment to be able to identify where we at and the gap we need to bridge.
What does that assessment look like?
What inputs do you take into account when you're helping someone understand if they're ready or not?
Okay, we usually take the data part, see how our client is connecting their their data, how are they extracting it, where are they loading it, and how are they using it.
And secondly, we take a look at their technology stack.
See their technology maturity.
See if they have the technology stack to be able to implement big Gen AI use cases or they still have like a big gap and we need to work on this technology architecture before moving on.
and also in the management change to see how the their employees are within AI, how much do they know about AI and what kind of workshops or or how can we try to make this change management plan for them to maximize the the use cases we will implement in the future.
When it comes to data, for someone who's listening to this and wondering whether their data is ready for an AI strategy, what are the considerations that come into play when evaluating whether data is clean and organized and ready to be ingested by a potential solution?
Mainly right now the main pipeline it's called ELT.
It can also be ETL.
It stands for extract, load and transform.
Okay.
So, you got to be able to extract the data from whatever your activity is.
If you're a bank, you need to be able to extract all the payments your clients make each day.
And after extracting all the data in real time, you got to be able to load it into your databases to be able to have it correctly structure over there.
And then you need to or it's easier if you are able to transform the data that it's already loaded in your database.
So it's easier for AI to work on that.
We've just seen the MCP protocol that open AAI just adopt from cloud and that's a big example on how data and structuring data will accelerate AI adoption and what and how AI will maximize it impact through data.
How much does that change how much work needs to be done with regards to structuring your data?
Exactly.
Well, the MCP protocol, for example, it's a really good example because it shows you how just by having a a type of guidelines on how to extract or use an a specific type of data will help the whole enterprise to know okay this our data for our client part it's built this way.
It's a it's a structure in a protocol way following these guidelines.

You've talked about a prioritization matrix.

That will be the second step of identifying use cases which is one of the main parts of our strategic offering.
So after these workshops I've mentioned we have a usually a long long list of use cases and we need to see what the real impact is of each use case.
So what we usually do is we try to build parame parameterization matrix which has as you said two axis it has impact in in and value in the business and physibility.
So for impact in the business, we usually take a look at what's the initial investment that needs to be made to deploy this use case.
What's the cost of scaling this use case in the future?
What's the efficiency that this use case will bring?
And how will this um how will this make an impact on the on the OPEX in in our business?
And then we will take a look at new incomes that this use case may bring, new clients, uh new business lines, whatever.
And then we'll take a look at non-tangible incomes like being more h having a a better look as a company cuz you're more echofriendly for example.
Okay.
How can that impact?
And this matrix has weights which are parametricized with our client.
So if our client's strategic plan is focusing in reducing cost or being more echofriendly, we will have these criterias have a bigger weight on our matrix so that our usea our prioritized use cases are the ones that will feed with their strategic plans.
So same thing goes with visibility.
We take a look at the data needed for the use case and the gap we need to close between what what the company has with their data right now and what they need of data for this use case their technology stack the implementation cost.
So we take a look at how much it's it's going to cost in effort and therefore time and money to deploy this use case.
Not all not all AI use cases are the same.
There are simple use cases.
There are big use cases and there are really complex use cases.
So we take a look at the effort we need to well the the company needs is going to need to do in order to deploy this use case and we take a look at all the regulations okay as part of physibility.
It's not the same if you're in an specific area with a lot of regulations followed by different axs that are going on in in the different regions.
It's not the same US then it's in Europe then it's in China for example.
So we take a look at like are are this use case it's going to have this impact in in the business but is it really worth it?
How how much is it worth it?
So that's where we leverage the the visibility to try and weigh things up and see if it makes sense or not or like which ones are the best fitted for now.
Yeah.
And that's how we prioritize this this matrix cuz maybe you have a really really good use case which it just isn't for now.
Maybe the gap you need to bridge for you to deploy that use case is really big and will will make a really big economic effort for the company to to deploy that that use case.
But maybe in a in a six month when your technology stack it's more mature.
It's a it's a really interesting use case cuz that use case in the in the impact th in the impact criteria was a use case that we saw it has a really big roy really easy payback or really good net value.
So that's the way we prioritize and we are able to not leave them behind not forget those use cases but still have them in our watch list.
So if in the future, you know, the technology stack, the data, it probably gets more mature in the in our in our client.
So we're going to be able to remake the framework and be able to see if it's fitted for for deploying in the future.

Okay, we take a look at the capex and the opex, and mainly the opex.
We want to see what type of use case are we building.
Is it a virtual assistant where our user is going to be interacting with the client?
Because in that case, there's a lot of monetization of the input token and output token, and that input token and output token really variates from GPT40 with DIP, which is open source, for example.
So it's a really important thing if when we scale the solution, we can also try to look for strategies in our AI app, which will consider or evaluate the question, and depending upon the complexity of the question, we will call it one LLM or other LLM in order to save money.
Okay, if you're, if our AI app is being asked what's 2 plus 2, we don't need to call GPT40, because any small model can do that sum for you.
So, we're going to be able to, we can offer a strategy to, um, okay, let's have this money just for complex situations or for complex answers.
And that's a thing that really needs to be a focus, and we really take care of it.

It's not the same for a model that needs to extract, uh, it needs to text from data from, for example, you know, PDFs, if it's a 10-page PDF or if it's a 100-page PDF.
So we also take a look at what the monetization of extracting the data is, which is different from the tokens with a built virtual assistant.

Well, we, in parallel to these use cases, we defined an architecture, and we also defined a model with the controls needed according to regulation.
In our case, in Europe, is the AI Act, AU AI Act.
And well, those three lines, apart from the change management plan we talked about and the operative model we redefine, but the main tangible things were these four use cases, which now we're scaling, and the AI architecture, which we are implementing too.
So right now, we're working parallel in these two work streams.
First one, we're scaling the four use cases, apart from we're going to start developing another three use cases as MVPs, but we're scaling those four, and then we're building an agnostic AI architecture to be able to accelerate the new use cases, be able to host our scalable use cases in the AI architecture and accelerate all the new development of use cases, so that it's easier for them to, as we've talked before, to bring impact out of a use case as fast as possible.
Yeah.
And what does that AI architecture look like?
Maybe not specifically, given this is a client, but in general, what are the components of a...
Well, that's actually, it's actually a big thing that right now maybe not all clients are considering, because a lot of clients are building the architecture just for the use case.
So if you have a use case where you need some monetization or some evaluation or maybe some pro gesture, you'll just build it for the use case, but you're not, you're not really building agnostic architectures, which are really going to accelerate new use cases.
Okay.
So architecture, and I think what architecture should look like is, um, uh, built in microservices, and it's really important, or I see it's really important to be agnostic to any technology.
Right now, AI is a really newly ecosystem, and it's changing every time to time.
You don't want to be locked in with a vendor and then finding out that after a year, it's not the best solution anymore, and you've built your whole architecture based on an specific solution, and it's harder for you to go back and deploy another different solution.
So I think it's really important to have an agnostic AI solution, AI architecture solution, which has the different components, different microservices, the orchestrator, the evaluator, the wad rails, and then on those different microservices, they are probably in different instances or in a docker file where they can be treated separately, and they could be developed and scaled separately.
Then you can see what the best option is right now in the market.
But knowing that you're building it as different microservices for you to be able to scale it, change it, and make any adjustment to each different component as a separate part as one.
So you're not going to impact the whole ecosystem, the whole architecture, and it's going to be easier for you to adapt to the new trends.
Yeah.
